title: Andromeda Galaxy
summary: The nearest major galaxy to the Milky Way, located about 2.5 million light-years away. It is on a collision course with our galaxy.

title: Apollo Program
summary: A series of United States human spaceflight missions undertaken by NASA, which landed the first humans on the Moon from 1969 to 1972.

title: Asteroid
summary: A small rocky body orbiting the Sun. Large numbers of these, ranging in size from nearly 600 miles (1,000 km) across (Ceres) to dust particles, are found, especially between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.

title: Aurora
summary: A natural light display in Earth's sky, predominantly seen in high-latitude regions (around the Arctic and Antarctic). Auroras are produced when the magnetosphere is sufficiently disturbed by the solar wind.

title: Big Bang Theory
summary: The prevailing cosmological model explaining the origin and evolution of the universe from an initial state of extremely high density and temperature.

title: Black Hole
summary: A region in spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing—no particles or even electromagnetic radiation such as light—can escape from it.

title: Comet
summary: An icy, small Solar System body that, when passing close to the Sun, warms and begins to release gases, a process called outgassing. This produces a visible atmosphere or coma, and sometimes also a tail.

title: Constellation
summary: A group of stars forming a recognizable pattern that is traditionally named after its apparent form or identified with a mythological figure.

title: Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB)
summary: The faint cosmic background radiation filling all space. It is an important source of data on the early universe because it is the oldest electromagnetic radiation in the universe, dating to the epoch of recombination.

title: Dark Energy
summary: A mysterious form of energy that is hypothesized to permeate all of space, tending to accelerate the expansion of the universe.

title: Dark Matter
summary: A form of matter thought to account for approximately 85% of the matter in the universe and about a quarter of its total mass–energy density. Its presence is implied in a variety of astrophysical observations.

title: Dwarf Planet
summary: A celestial body orbiting the Sun that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity but has not cleared its orbital region of other objects. Pluto is a well-known example.

title: Earth
summary: The third planet from the Sun and the only astronomical object known to harbor life. It has a dynamic atmosphere, vast oceans, and diverse ecosystems.

title: Exoplanet
summary: A planet that orbits a star outside our solar system. Thousands have been discovered, exhibiting a wide range of sizes, compositions, and orbital characteristics.

title: Galaxy
summary: A gravitationally bound system of stars, stellar remnants, interstellar gas, dust, and dark matter. Galaxies range in size from dwarfs with a few hundred million stars to giants with one hundred trillion stars.

title: Gamma-Ray Burst (GRB)
summary: Extremely energetic explosions that have been observed in distant galaxies. They are the brightest electromagnetic events known to occur in the universe.

title: Gravitational Lensing
summary: A phenomenon where light from a source (such as a galaxy or quasar) is bent by the gravity of a massive object (such as another galaxy or a cluster of galaxies) lying between the source and the observer.

title: Gravity
summary: The force that attracts a body toward the center of the earth, or toward any other physical body having mass. It is one of the four fundamental forces of nature.

title: Hubble Space Telescope (HST)
summary: A space telescope launched into low Earth orbit in 1990 and still in operation. It has made numerous groundbreaking discoveries in astronomy.

title: Interstellar Medium (ISM)
summary: The matter and radiation that exist in the space between the star systems in a galaxy. This matter includes gas in ionic, atomic, and molecular form, as well as dust and cosmic rays.

title: International Space Station (ISS)
summary: A modular space station in low Earth orbit. It is a multinational collaborative project involving five participating space agencies: NASA (United States), Roscosmos (Russia), JAXA (Japan), ESA (Europe), and CSA (Canada).

title: James Webb Space Telescope (JWST)
summary: A space telescope designed primarily to conduct infrared astronomy. As the largest optical telescope in space, its greatly improved infrared resolution and sensitivity allow it to view objects too old, distant, or faint for the Hubble Space Telescope.

title: Jupiter
summary: The fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in the Solar System. It is a gas giant with a mass more than two and a half times that of all the other planets in the Solar System combined.

title: Kepler Space Telescope
summary: A retired space telescope launched by NASA to discover Earth-size planets orbiting other stars. It found thousands of exoplanets using the transit method.

title: Kuiper Belt
summary: A circumstellar disc in the outer Solar System, extending from the orbit of Neptune at 30 astronomical units (AU) to approximately 50 AU from the Sun. It is similar to the asteroid belt, but is far larger—20 times as wide and 20–200 times as massive.

title: Light-Year
summary: A unit of astronomical distance equivalent to the distance that light travels in one year, which is 9.4607 × 10^12 km (nearly 6 trillion miles).

title: Mars
summary: The fourth planet from the Sun and the second-smallest planet in the Solar System, being larger than only Mercury. Mars carries a prominent red color, due to the prevalence of iron oxide on its surface.

title: Meteoroid, Meteor, Meteorite
summary: A meteoroid is a small rocky or metallic body in outer space. A meteor is the streak of light seen when a meteoroid enters Earth's atmosphere and burns up. A meteorite is a meteoroid that survives its passage through the atmosphere and lands on the surface.

title: Milky Way Galaxy
summary: The galaxy that includes our Solar System. It is a barred spiral galaxy estimated to contain 100–400 billion stars and at least that number of planets.

title: Moon (Earth's Moon)
summary: Earth's only natural satellite. It is the fifth largest moon in the Solar System and the largest relative to the size of its planet.

title: NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration)
summary: An independent agency of the U.S. federal government responsible for the civilian space program, as well as aeronautics and space research.

title: Nebula
summary: An interstellar cloud of dust, hydrogen, helium and other ionized gases. Nebulae are often star-forming regions, such as in the Eagle Nebula.

title: Neutron Star
summary: The collapsed core of a massive supergiant star, which had a total mass of between 10 and 25 solar masses, possibly more if the star was metal-rich. Except for black holes, neutron stars are the smallest and densest currently known class of stellar objects.

title: Orbit
summary: The gravitationally curved trajectory of an object, such as the trajectory of a planet around a star or a natural satellite around a planet.

title: Planet
summary: A celestial body that (a) is in orbit around the Sun, (b) has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium (nearly round) shape, and (c) has cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit.

title: Pulsar
summary: A highly magnetized rotating neutron star that emits beams of electromagnetic radiation out of its magnetic poles. This radiation can be observed only when a beam of emission is pointing toward Earth.

title: Quasar
summary: An extremely luminous active galactic nucleus (AGN), powered by a supermassive black hole at the center of a galaxy, surrounded by a gaseous accretion disk.

title: Red Giant
summary: A luminous giant star of low or intermediate mass (roughly 0.3–8 solar masses (M☉)) in a late phase of stellar evolution. The outer atmosphere is inflated and tenuous, making the radius large and the surface temperature low.

title: Rocket
summary: A spacecraft, aircraft, vehicle or projectile that obtains thrust from a rocket engine. Rocket engine exhaust is formed entirely from propellant carried within the rocket.

title: Satellite
summary: An artificial body placed in orbit around the Earth or another planet in order to collect information or for communication. Also refers to a celestial body orbiting the Earth or another planet (e.g., the Moon).

title: Solar Flare
summary: A sudden flash of increased brightness on the Sun, usually observed near its surface and in close proximity to a sunspot group. Powerful flares are often, but not always, accompanied by a coronal mass ejection.

title: Solar System
summary: The gravitationally bound system of the Sun and the objects that orbit it, either directly or indirectly. Of the objects that orbit the Sun directly, the largest are the eight planets.

title: Solar Wind
summary: A stream of charged particles (a plasma) released from the upper atmosphere of the Sun. It mostly consists of electrons, protons and alpha particles with kinetic energy between 0.5 and 10 keV.

title: Space Shuttle Program
summary: NASA's fourth human spaceflight program that developed and operated a partially reusable low Earth orbital spacecraft system from 1981 to 2011.

title: Spacetime
summary: In physics, spacetime is any mathematical model which fuses the three dimensions of space and the one dimension of time into a single four-dimensional manifold. Spacetime diagrams can be used to visualize relativistic effects.

title: Star
summary: An astronomical object consisting of a luminous spheroid of plasma held together by its own gravity. The nearest star to Earth is the Sun.

title: Sun
summary: The star at the center of the Solar System. It is a nearly perfect sphere of hot plasma, heated to incandescence by nuclear fusion reactions in its core.

title: Supernova
summary: A powerful and luminous stellar explosion. This transient astronomical event occurs during the last evolutionary stages of a massive star or when a white dwarf is triggered into runaway nuclear fusion.

title: Telescope
summary: An optical instrument designed to make distant objects appear nearer, containing an arrangement of lenses, or of curved mirrors and lenses, by which rays of light are collected and focused and the resulting image magnified.

title: Universe
summary: All of space and time and their contents, including planets, stars, galaxies, and all other forms of matter and energy.

title: Voyager Program
summary: An American scientific program that employs two robotic interstellar probes, Voyager 1 and Voyager 2. They were launched in 1977 to take advantage of a favorable alignment of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune.

title: White Dwarf
summary: A stellar core remnant composed mostly of electron-degenerate matter. A white dwarf is very dense: its mass is comparable to that of the Sun, while its volume is comparable to that of Earth.

title: Wormhole
summary: A speculative structure linking disparate points in spacetime, and is based on a special solution of the Einstein field equations. A wormhole can be visualized as a tunnel with two ends at separate points in spacetime.

title: X-ray Astronomy
summary: The branch of astronomy concerned with the study of X-ray emission from celestial objects. X-rays are absorbed by the Earth's atmosphere, so instruments to detect X-rays must be taken to high altitude by balloons, sounding rockets, and satellites.

title: Xenon
summary: A chemical element with symbol Xe and atomic number 54. It is a colorless, dense, odorless noble gas. Xenon is used in ion propulsion systems for spacecraft due to its high atomic weight and ease of ionization.

title: Yerkes Observatory
summary: An astronomical observatory located in Williams Bay, Wisconsin, U.S.A. It was operated by the University of Chicago Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics from its founding in 1897 to 2018. It houses the largest refracting telescope ever used for astronomical research.

title: Yellow Dwarf
summary: A G-type main-sequence star (spectral type G V). Such a star has about 0.9 to 1.1 solar masses and surface temperature of between 5,300 and 6,000 K. Like other main-sequence stars, a G-type main-sequence star is converting the element hydrogen to helium in its core by means of nuclear fusion. Our Sun is the best-known example.

title: Zenith
summary: In astronomy and navigation, the zenith is an imaginary point directly "above" a particular location, on the imaginary celestial sphere. "Above" means in the vertical direction opposite to the gravity direction at that location (nadir).

title: Zodiacal Light
summary: A faint, diffuse, and roughly triangular white glow that is visible in the night sky and appears to extend from the Sun's direction and along the zodiac. It is sunlight scattered by interplanetary dust. Zodiacal light is best seen during twilight after sunset in spring and before sunrise in autumn.
